node_definition: Whether it is a born-digital record, digitised record or surrogate.Born-Digital records are digital materials which have have originated from a digital source.Surrogates are digital materials which have been created as a result of converting analogue originals where we do hold the analogue original. (They are surrogate as the analogue is the official record).Digitised records are digital materials which have been created as a result of converting analogue originals, but we do not hold the analogue original.
Descriptive metadata and custodial history information.
Knowing of the conditions of use and any restrictions, including the legal status, copyright, who owns the intellectual property, Freedom of Information restrictions etc.
Having full knowledge of the material content, provenance and conditions of use.
Knowing what the material is and where it is from.
Information to allow for fixity checks on the file.
Whether the file format is open or proprietary, and whether or not it is ubiquitous.
Whether the technical metadata has the complete information required to know what to expct from a full render.
Availability of tools and software to render the digital material, inculding to do format migrations and emulations.
The ability to render the digital object as originally intended.
Maintaining the integrity of a digital object and verifying it has not been altered or corrupted.
The bit stream is secure against malicious or accidental damage
Internal systems and support for coherent information management and documentation of preservation actions

Bespoke digital preservation skills such as awareness of tecnological trends, detailed knowledge of storage media, hardware and software, skills to perform file format migration, skills to find or build emulating software etc.
Essential equipment, hardware or software required to access the bit stream becoming obsolete.
A term used to denote a very basic level of preservation of digital resource as it was submitted (literally preservation of the bits forming a digital resource).
Whether the conditions are optimal and you have mitigation strategies in place to protect against physical disasters.
Whether you will always have access to at least two copies of the digital material.
A sudden accident or a natural catastrophe that causes great physical damage.
Whether the storage media is undamaged and functioning as expected.
The type of medium on which the digital objects are stored.
